files.name: spaceone/api/cost_analysis/v1/budget.proto
files.description: A Budget is a planned amount of cost expenditure for reduction and prediction of infrastructure costs.

fields.name: start
fields.description: Start date of the budget, e.g. 2025-01

fields.name: end
fields.description: End date of the budget, e.g. 2025-12

fields.name: currency
fields.description: Currency of the budget, e.g. USD, KRW, JPY

fields.name: limit
fields.description:
Only `TOTAL` time_unit budget can be updated
+optional

methods.name: create
methods.description: Creates a new Budget. When creating a Budget, it should be set for a specific ProjectGroup or Project. The budgeted amount and date of the `planned_limits` should be specified on a monthly or yearly basis.

methods.name: update
methods.description: Updates a specific Budget. You can make changes in the budgeted amount of the time period specified while creating the resource.

methods.name: set_notification
methods.description: Sets a notification on a specific Budget. Sets a threshold on the budget, and if the cost exceeds the threshold, a notification is raised.

methods.name: delete
methods.description: Deletes a specific Budget. You must specify the `budget_id` of the Budget to delete.

methods.name: get
methods.description: Gets a specific Budget. Prints detailed information about the Budget, including `planned_limits` of the project group or project for the pre-defined period.

methods.name: list
methods.description: Gets a list of all Budgets. You can use a query to get a filtered list of Budgets.

scalarValueTypes.notes: Uses variable-length encoding. Inefficient for encoding negative numbers  if your field is likely to have negative values, use sint32 instead.
Uses variable-length encoding. Inefficient for encoding negative numbers  if your field is likely to have negative values, use sint64 instead.
Uses variable-length encoding. Signed int value. These more efficiently encode negative numbers than regular int32s.
Uses variable-length encoding. Signed int value. These more efficiently encode negative numbers than regular int64s.
Always four bytes. More efficient than uint32 if values are often greater than 2^28.
Always eight bytes. More efficient than uint64 if values are often greater than 2^56.
A string must always contain UTF-8 encoded or 7-bit ASCII text.
May contain any arbitrary sequence of bytes.
